“Why do you look so sad?” Raskolnikov asked.

“Better at home,” Svidrigaïlov replied. “Here, I blame others.”

“Have you heard? Berg is going up in a balloon.”

“Would you go up?” Raskolnikov wondered.

“No, oh no,” Svidrigaïlov muttered, deep in thought.

“Why not?”

“It was my choice to stay. Marfa Petrovna gave me money. She trusted me.”

“Missing her?” Raskolnikov asked.

“Perhaps. Do you believe in ghosts?” Svidrigaïlov's eyes glinted.

“What ghosts?” 

“Ordinary ones,” he smiled strangely. “Marfa visits me.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Svidrigaïlov reflects on his past and the influence of Marfa Petrovna while contemplating the idea of ghosts.
